ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: My responses in questions 8 to 10 refer to Tomer Fishman and not to Edgar Hertwich.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: The course left me with a series of steps on how to read scientific articles in a more careful way. I also can evaluate more critically papers that I would have trusted 'blindly' before.
-Comprehensive overview of relevant literature -Structure of class logical with good flow -Ample opportunity for in-class discussion -Expert instructors

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: Maybe time management in class is an area of improvement.
-Perhaps more structured discussion -More visual aids during class

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Useful to my overall research, lot of important background.

Although the course is out of my main professional area of interest, it helped me to have a more critical understanding of scientific literature and it provided me an overview of the field of industrial ecology.
As a PhD student in Industrial Ecology, having an in-depth understanding of these foundational texts is very helpful in forming my own perspectives on important next steps for research in the field.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: I wanted some exposure to the field of socioeconomic metabolism. I think the course description was very attractive to me, too.
- recommended by my supervisor - applies to my own PhD research
To deepen my understanding of the topic. I have utilized the methods of Material Flow Analysis in prior research, but I was unaware of how they have been applied at the economy-wide level.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: My expectations were more centered on the contents than on any specific skills. I think I gained this unexpected skill on reading critically scientific literature, which is very much appreciated.
- A more in-depth coverage of methods would have been appreciated
Yes, I am much more versed in SocioEconomic Metabolism now.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Note that this course is a seminar, which means is primarily directed to science-based students and is centered on the review of existing scientific literature on the field of socioeconomic metabolism. It can be a good overview if you want to have an exposure to industrial ecology.
Do all the reading, take notes as you read, and come prepared to discuss!
